captions.text: After Limbo one year and Bastion the next, I've come to look forward to the Xbox Live Summer of Arcade the way a child in a small town would look forward to when the carnival arrives so he can spend all his money and learn a harsh lesson about reality and spiders. It's like a little opportunity for some indie games about big-headed children exploring grim environments
I'm not sure if I'm allowed to come within earshot of AAA console gaming and be allowed to stand in the corner of the banqueting hall, occasionally ducking the odd chicken bone.
And yet I have to say I'm disappointed by the showing this year. It started badly when the first release was an HD remake of Tony Hawk Pro Skater.
How does that evoke the indie spirit of the XBLA? Tony Hawk's head isn't even particularly big, and he could hardly be said to be exploring a big scary world.
He's just farting about on a bit of wood, being paid too much money to not get a proper job. Yeah, alright, glasshouses.
But since then it's only been downhill. First a Kinect-only game, then a zombie apocalypse game. But let's take a closer look at them anyway.
Maybe they figured out how to make Kinect fun, and Zombies original, and maybe I'm about to poo out a Cadillac Escalade.

The Kinect one is Wreckateer, a physics game in which you fling a set number of projectiles with various different properties at loosely constructed buildings at the expense of small round green sods.
And this might strike you as familiar if the front page of the iPhone app store has ever been hurled past your front window so that you caught a glimpse of it for one tenth of a nanosecond.

Yes it Angry Birds but in full 3D except with the suicide sparrows replaced with good honest traditional rocks because this is the XBLA and we don tolerate that quirky mobile device nonsense At the encouragement of two guys who look like they were rendered in the late 90s you
have to operate an imaginary ballista with hand movements and stances that make you look
like you're preparing to catch a rugby ball from someone being attacked by a crow.
Unlike Angry Birds, though, you also make course corrections mid-flight by slapping
the missile like... like there's something directly in front of you, say, at around waist
height that for one reason or another you want to give a good hard spanking.
I will say this, I think Kinect is the least obnoxious he's ever been in this game.
He's still wearing a lampshade and burping at my gran, but at least he's not hammering
nails into the soles of my feet.
I think because it never tries to call upon quick reflexes.
You have all the time in the world to position yourself for the right firing angle, and more
importantly the Kinect has all the time in the world to figure out where in the room
you have moved to and how many limbs you currently possess.
Which is not to say that I and my spine wouldn't prefer to play it with a normal controller,
or indeed on a mobile device, for about 8000 levels and counting.
